search.query: `fb_data_from_today` state="hot" OR state="warm" `_fb_summary_recs($host$, $index$)` | bucket _time span=1d | eval state=mvappend(state, if(endEpoch>now(), "ballast", null())) | stats max(sizeOnDiskMB) AS sizeOnDiskMB by _time, path, index, state

html.div:
The family of views in the Retention menu is aimed at helping administrators visualize and thereby tune various retention parameters for their indexed data. General information about retention settings can be found in the Splunk documentation for version 6.0.x here.
This dashboard is focused on limits based upon the count of buckets within the index. Only buckets in the hot and warm states can be limited by count.
Within the Warm Buckets panel, three quantities are shown. The first is the current count of buckets in this state. The second, labeled "Ballast" represents the counts of buckets which have time stamps in the future. These buckets may not pass through the bucket lifecyle in a normal way. The third value shown within this panel is the current limit, as provided in indexes.conf.
The chart below, titled Usage vs. Configured Maximum Count (Hot / Warm Only), shows "Count:" and "Limit:" values over the hot and warm states. If there are ballast buckets, a count of these will be shown as well.

search.query: | inputlookup fb_hostname_index_cache | stats count by orig_host
| inputlookup fb_hostname_index_cache where orig_host=$host$ | stats count by orig_index
search state="ballast" | stats count, sum(count) AS ballast

chart.title: Usage vs. Configured Maximum Count (Hot / Warm Only)

search.query: state="hot" OR state="warm" `_fb_summary_recs($host$, $index$)` | bucket _time span=1d | eval state=mvappend(state, if(endEpoch>now(), "ballast", null())) | stats max(sizeOnDiskMB) AS sizeOnDiskMB by _time, path, index, state | lookup fb_services_data_indexes_cache splunk_server, title AS index OUTPUT maxHotBuckets maxWarmDBCount | eval limit=if(state=="hot", maxHotBuckets, if(state=="warm", maxWarmDBCount, 0)) | timechart span=1d dc(path) AS "Count", first(limit) AS Limit by state | rename comment AS "Just in case..." | fields - "Limit: ballast"
